source: **Objective**: to verify that irrespective of the underlying probability distribution of a random variable, X, the sampling distribution of Xbar (mean of X) will approach a Normal Distribution as sample size n increases.

## imports

import numpy as np 
import pandas as pd
from datetime import datetime
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

import pprint
pp = pprint.PrettyPrinter(indent=4)

import statistics
%matplotlib inline

import random

## Reads in Dataframe from USGS CSV, removes unneed data
rain_df = pd.read_csv('/content/Bos-Sea_Daily_1948-2020.csv')
boston_df = rain_df.drop(columns=['STATION','NAME','DATE','PRCP (in.)'])
boston_df

source:
1. Use 1948-2020 Boston Annual Total Rainfall as your original time series, X(t) with 73 values (1948-2020):
*   Estimate the first four moments for this time series.
*   Plot the Histogram and discuss what type of distribution will best represent the underlying probability distribution.

## Calculation of mean
mean = np.mean(boston_df['PRCP (in.).1'])
mean

## Calculation of variance
std = np.std(boston_df['PRCP (in.).1'])
variance = np.var(boston_df['PRCP (in.).1'])
variance

## Calculation of Skewness
skewness = boston_df['PRCP (in.).1'].skew()
skewness

## Calculation of Kurtosis
kurtosis = boston_df['PRCP (in.).1'].kurtosis()
kurtosis

## Plot of Histogram
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.xlabel('PRCP (in.)')
plt.title('Frequency of PRCP values')
ax = boston_df['PRCP (in.).1'].plot.hist(bins=30)

2. Use different sample size, n (e.g., 1, 5, 10, 20, and 40) and show how that effects the estimates of Xbar and Standard Deviation of Xbar. To do this, use 100 “randomly chosen” realizations from the original time series.

## First of many functions to vary sample size of 100 randomly chosen realization from the original time series
def varySampleSize(sample_size): 
  random.seed(10)
  mean_list = []
  count = 0

  while count < 100:
    mean_list.append(np.mean(boston_df['PRCP (in.).1'].sample(n=sample_size).values))
    count = count + 1

  xbar_est = sum(mean_list)/len(mean_list)
  std_xbar = statistics.stdev(mean_list) 

  pp.pprint(f'For a sampe size of {sample_size}, the estimate of xbar is {xbar_est} and the standard deviation for xbar is {std_xbar}.')

  plt.hist(mean_list, density=False, bins=30)
varySampleSize(1) ## This histogram suggest thats with n = 1, the distribution remains exponential,  just as the original data was.

outputs.name: stdout
text:
('For a sampe size of 1, the estimate of xbar is 0.12009999999999998 and the '

source:
3. Create a Normalized Boston Annual Total Rainfall series defined as:
X’ = (X-Xbar)/St Dev (X)

## Function to normalize PRCP values
def zNormalize(x):
  normal = (x-mean)/std
  return normal  
boston_df['PRCP normal'] = boston_df['PRCP (in.).1'].apply(zNormalize)

## Plot of normalized Histogram
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.xlabel('PRCP normal')
plt.title('Frequency of PRCP values')
ax = boston_df['PRCP normal'].plot.hist(bins=30)
4. Repeat (2) with X’

def varySampleSizeNormal(sample_size):
  random.seed(10) 
  mean_list = []
  count = 0

  while count < 100:
    mean_list.append(np.mean(boston_df['PRCP (in.).1'].sample(n=sample_size).values)) 
    count = count + 1

  normal_list = []

  for value in mean_list:
    normal = (value - (sum(mean_list)/len(mean_list)))/statistics.stdev(mean_list)
    normal_list.append(normal)

  pp.pprint(f'For a sampe size of {sample_size}, the estimate of xbar is {np.mean(normal_list)} and the standard deviation for xbar is {np.std(normal_list)}.')

  plt.hist(normal_list, density=False, bins=30)
varySampleSizeNormal(1) ## Like above, at n = 1, the sample mean has an expontential distribution, due to the original data.

source: 5. Simulate Y as a Normally Distributed Random Variable with zero mean and unit variance

mu, sigma = 0, 1
s = np.random.normal(mu, sigma, 100)
count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 30, density=True)

6. Examine the properties of the following four random variables under what situations the sampling distribution of the following random variables support (refute) the notion of the Central Limit Theorem:
*  A1 = X
*  A2= X’
*  A3 = X’ + Y
*  A4 = X’ + Y + R (a normalized random variable of your choice)
## A1: When taking the sample mean of a set of the random variables in X, I found that the distribution of the sample mean approaches normal.

## A2 Applying the same moethodology to the values normalized as X', I found that the distribution of the sample mean also approaches normal and did so with a lower n than in X. That being said, n must still be larger than 10 for normalization to be observed.
w = makeNormalArray(40) + s
plt.hist(w, density=False, bins=30)

## When sampling a distribution of the random variables in X'+Y, I found that the distribution of the sample mean approaches normal. This feature of the Central Limit Theorem is described in greater detail below in A4.
#See below for A4

7. Do another analysis with a dataset of your own choice to examine the robustness of the Central Limit Theorem to address real world problems with small “n”.

For this example, I chose to document word frequency across one of my favorite books, Alexandre Dumas's *The Three Musketeers*, taken courtesy  of Project Gutenberg. As we see below, this data set is very heavily left-skewed and much like the rain fall data above, looks exponential in distribution. This initial observation makes sense: usually the number of unique words, that is words only used one time, signficantly outweights that of non-unique words, words like 'the' or 'a', which are used in almost every sentence.

Also seen below, if we apply the same methodology as above to take a random set of sample means and plot them, we see that, as n gets large, the distribution tends towards normal. However, unlike above where we saw this normality after n = 20-30, this data set only observes normality after n is much larger, around 200-500. Thus, while the Central Limit Theorem is preserved and shown to be valid for this data set, it reminds us that in some situations n must be very large for the CLT to be observable.

musketeers_df = countWords('/content/threemusketeers.txt')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.xlabel('Frequency of word in text')
plt.title('Frequency of word values')
ax = musketeers_df[0].plot.hist(bins=30) ## Like an exaggerated form of the rainfall data, this data is exponential because there are more words that are only used once than those that are used more than once.

def varySampleSizeNormalMuskeeters(sample_size): 
  random.seed(10)
  mean_list = []
  count = 0

  while count < 100:
    mean_list.append(np.mean(musketeers_df[0].sample(n=sample_size).values))
    count = count + 1

  normal_list = []

  for value in mean_list:
    normal = (value - (sum(mean_list)/len(mean_list)))/statistics.stdev(mean_list)
    normal_list.append(normal)

  pp.pprint(f'For a sampe size of {sample_size}, the estimate of xbar is {np.mean(normal_list)} and the standard deviation for xbar is {np.std(normal_list)}.')

  plt.hist(normal_list, density=False, bins=30)
varySampleSizeNormalMuskeeters(1) ## As with the rainfall data, at n = 1 the original distribution is visible, with a few minor differences.

source: v = makeNormalArrayMuskeeters(40) + makeNormalArray(40) + s
plt.hist(v, density=False, bins=30)

## We see that although the distribution of the sample mean at n = 40 for the normalized Three Musketeer data does not resemble a normal distribution, adding it to two other distributions which we have observed as normal yields a normal distribution.

## This result suggests that irrespective of the underlying probability distribution and given an equal sample size, that probability distribution will tend towards normal. This observartion comes as a corollary to the Central Limit Theorem: we can hypothesize that the more normal-looking distributions that we add to an otherwise non-normal distribution will coerce that distribution to be normal.
